We are lucky we live in a time where many chronic diseases are becoming nearly invisible because of new therapies. Access to care remains a challenge for some & that must be changed, now, in this timeline. (End) https://t.co/XlgScSBSVt

There are a variety of medications now available, though regardless of which one you use, it’s critical they be used correctly. That’s ok, spacers aren’t too big & with good control, rescue meds hopefully won’t be needed often. Spacer info here: https://t.co/rcdpi9WxCg https://t.co/HBB86V8pvV

Actually, because of clear protocols, the bulk of cases are handled by primary care docs, with only the most severe needing care by a pediatric pulmonologist/allergist. The goal of treatment is to minimize symptoms so kids can normally participate in physical activity. https://t.co/PRhRSO2j7R

Did you know asthma is the most common chronic disease in children? ~5.5 million US children have it. The good news is that there have been huge improvements in therapy protocols. This means that the majority of kids with asthma can lead normal lives with appropriate therapy.🧵 https://t.co/Ae0E3XweQn

So please continue to work to lessen disease transmission. Get vaccinated & boosted if you qualify, get children vaccinated when able, wear a high quality mask (thanks omicron) when around others, stay home when sick unless you need medical care. (10/10)

There are a ton of things that are dangerous for kids, not just covid. We know that. No need to create a false dichotomy here. But just like w car safety, swimming safety, poison prevention, safe infant sleep, etc. we will always opt to tip the scales towards improved health (9/)

And it is a big deal for all the HCWs who chose pediatrics not because they thought it would be lollipops & rainbows, but instead want to do everything they can to help children & families reach their fullest potential and keep kids safe. (8/)

Please don’t discount any child’s life by saying “I bet it’s gone from 1 to 4, so no big deal”. It is a big deal for that child who without covid would not be in the hospital. It is a big deal for the parents who worry for their child. It is a big deal for those missing work (7/)

So, yeah, NY Pediatricians are worried about the @HealthNYGov statement on hospitalization surges in the city. There isn’t room for the adult hospitals to help like we did in the past. Anything we can do to lessen disease burden, we need to do. (6/) https://t.co/sOfIpkF0Ol

When there are 5-10 additional highly infectious patients that need hospitalization, you can see why it’s actually a big deal. 
Plus, my earlier point: kids don’t usually get hospitalized, so when they do it’s a big deal for the child & family even if they fully recover (5/)

Historically, between flu & RSV, all the beds would be full throughout the winter. Last year, no flu or RSV, minimal peds covid hospitalizations  so some adults were cared for in ped’s hospitals because there was a huge need. This year, the germs are back. (4/)
There are a subset that need frequent hospitalizations and therefore have dedicated units (some of the 50 non-PICU beds), ie cancer patients & those w complex neurologic diseases. (3/)

The same for @UpstateGolisano and @OCHBuffalo- they are much smaller than their adult medicine counterparts, because in general, historically relatively few kids need hospitalization for medical problems compared to adults. (2/)

Why does it matter if there are an extra 10 or so kids admitted to a children’s hospital?  A 🧵on scale. 
@UR_Med is a 900 bed level I trauma center, it covers about 12 upstate counties. However, it’s pediatric equivalent, @URMed_GCH has only 74 beds (~24 are PICU) (1/) https://t.co/8FVBA8yGxh

Put another way, what day should offices be opening up blocks of time for vaccination? How much space can be dedicated to this? (the 15 min observation still applies so at best 4/hr/room) The vial info just came out so now we know 10 doses/vial. No one size fits all answers here.

The planning is well underway. Enough vaccine for all US children has been purchased & is being distributed in preparation for whatever the “go day” will be. But that’s the trick, when is “go day”? https://t.co/GR6OP9XR7y

Logistics: PCP offices are already packed (thanks RSV, Paraflu, & yes, Covid) so “just have a vaccine clinic” won’t work for all offices. Mass vaccination sites won’t work for a lot of little kids. So the way we do this will take a lot of local level planning.

The vials are different. 
Tricky news: 10 doses per vial, no one wants to waste any, so everyone is trying to be super efficient & kid friendly too.
Good news: storage is easier (no deep freeze needed)
Great news: Focus is on vaccinating in the medical home (ie your kid’s dr)
